title: There's no direct way of getting offset of a sentence w.r.t. a document.
body:
Many existing sentence segmentors such as those of NLTK or SpaCy give a list of sentence objects after splitting a document. The advantage of which is that one can get other information of a sentence from that object.

```
import spacy 
nlp = spacy.load('en_core_web_md')
document = "The child who has a rash. I don't know who has a rash. The reason why is unknown."
for sentence in nlp(document).sents:
    print (type(sentence))
    print (sentence.text)
    print (sentence.start_char) # offset of the sentence w.r.t. the document
```

**Output:**

> <class 'spacy.tokens.span.Span'>
> The child who has a rash.
> 0
> <class 'spacy.tokens.span.Span'>
> I don't know who has a rash.
> 26
> <class 'spacy.tokens.span.Span'>
> The reason why is unknown.
> 55
> 

However, syntok just provides sentence as a list of tokens and therefore one can not directly get the offset of the sentence.

```
import syntok.segmenter as segmenter
document = "The child who has a rash. I don't know who has a rash. The reason why is unknown."

for paragraph in segmenter.analyze(document):
    for sentence in paragraph:
        print (type(sentence))
        for token in sentence:
            # exactly reproduce the input
            # and do not remove "imperfections"
            print(token.spacing, token.value, sep='', end='')
        print("\n")  # reinsert paragraph separators
    print("\n")  # reinsert paragraph separators
```

**Output:**

> <class 'list'>
> The child who has a rash.
> 
> <class 'list'>
>  I don't know who has a rash.
> 
> <class 'list'>
>  The reason why is unknown.
> 

It would be great if syntok follows the similar way of defining a sentence (ie as an object and not as a list or so) in upcoming versions.
